title: What happens to Brexit if Boris Johnson’s deal fails?
text:
Boris Johnson would be legally obliged to ask for an extension but it is not that simple (Picture: PA)

Boris Johnson’s Brexit deal hangs on a knife-edge and he has spent the last 48 hours on a charm offensive with wavering MPs.

He needs to get 320 votes from Tory supporters and opposition rebels for it to pass through the House of Commons.

If it fails, the PM is compelled under the Benn Act to request a further extension to Article 50, meaning a delay until January 31 at the earliest.

This would crush Mr Johnson’s vow to deliver Brexit by October 31 ‘do or die.’

Addressing the House of Commons this morning, Mr Johnson said an extension would be ‘pointless, expensive and deeply corrosive of public trust.’

There are some concerns that the Government has been searching for a loophole to avoid having to request a delay.

For example, Mr Johnson could request an extension with one letter and then in another tell the EU to ignore the request.

This is likely to be tested in the UK courts by way of a legal challenge.

Opposition MPs came together to make a no-deal illegal

All 27 EU member states would have to agree to an extension and they could demand a longer term than January.

If they refuse, we would crash out of the bloc at 11pm on October 31 without a deal.

EU Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker has piled the pressure on MPs to back the deal by raising doubts over any further delay to the UK’s departure past the end of the month.

On Thursday, he said there was no point in a ‘prolongation’.

However, he was contradicted by European Council President Donald Tusk who said if there is a request for an extension he will ‘consult with other member states to see how they react’.

Friction-free trade with the UK and guaranteed rights for EU citizens mean that it is in everyone’s best interests to get a deal in place.

If no-deal is agreed, the UK would immediately exit the customs union and single market and default to World Trade regulations.

There are warnings this would plunge the UK into a recession while leaving millions of citizens in limbo about their rights.
